234.output: Temporal information extraction in text can be divided into two main tasks: recognizing temporal expressions and identifying time spans or intervals. Temporal expressions in text mainly include four categories: time point (e.g., Monday), time span (e.g., March 1st to March 5th), point duration (e.g., 3 years), and interval duration (e.g., in 20 years). Interval duration can be further divided into open duration (e.g., from five to six o'clock) and closed duration (e.g., from 7 am to 8 am), where closed durations have explicit temporal boundaries. Temporal expressions are generally ambiguous due to the lack of context. For example, a date (i.e., a temporal expression that can be associated with a date) may be meant to indicate a precise date or a date range. For date range expressions, the start date, end date, and inclusion of other dates are unclear. Other types of temporal expressions are also ambiguous due to the lack of additional information, such as “Sunday,” which can be meant to refer to the current, previous, or next Sunday. Furthermore, the ambiguity of temporal units can make the extraction of temporal information more challenging. For example, 6 months can refer to a duration measurement from six to twelve months, but can also be interpreted as two, three, or four periods of six months. Finally, the directionality of temporal expressions should be considered, e.g., two hours ago vs. two hours from now have different implications.</s>

1003.output: This model would be considered as a part of the pre-test of the clinical trial recruitment plan based on the patient eligibility criteria provided. This model does not consider the time frame for evaluation, and the results are based on only one parameter, the inclusion criteria. The eligibility of a patient is calculated based on the matching keywords for each eligibility criteria in the patient note and the inclusion criteria of the trial. The probability matching percentage determines the patient match for trial eligibility for each patient note. In the validation experiment, the best value of the hyperparameters was used as the input of the model. For the evaluation of the models, the eligibility results were calculated with the best model. These results are the probability matching percentage for each patient note. A patient note with a probability matching percentage > 0 indicates that the patient is referred for trial eligibility. A patient note with a probability matching percentage < 0 indicates that the patient is not referred for trial eligibility. A probability matching percentage of 0 would indicate that the patient note matches the exact trial inclusion criteria and none of the other criteria. During the validation and training of the model, to determine how the accuracy of the model performs on a new randomly selected sample of data, using a k-fold cross-validation method , . This method involves the random selection of 10% of the notes for validation and the remaining 90% of the notes for training. This procedure is repeated 10 times, with each round using a different 10% for validation and 90% for training.</s>

1558.output: Summary: Pneumonia is the leading cause of childhood morbidity and death in many developing countries including Bangladesh, causing about 2 million deaths worldwide each year. Pneumonia is an infection of the lungs, most commonly caused by viruses or bacteria like Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. Depending on the clinical presentation, pneumonia can be classified as very severe, severe or non-severe, with specific treatment for each of them except for antibiotic therapy. Severe and very severe pneumonia require hospitalization for additional supportive treatment such as suction, oxygen therapy and administration of bronchodilator. In Bangladesh, the number of hospital beds is inadequate for admission of all pneumonia cases that require hospitalization; however, it is also important to provide institutional care to those children who cannot be hospitalized due to bed constraints. Provision of appropriate antibiotics and supportive cares during the period of stay at established day-care centres could be an effective alternative. The impetus for this study came from the findings of our recently completed study titled Daycare-based management of severe pneumonia in under-5 children when hospitalization is not possible due to the lack of beds. This study successfully managed children (n=251), but it was not a randomized trial and thus direct comparison of the efficacy of management of severe pneumonia at the day-care centre, essential for building confidence for implementing this management policy, is not possible. We, the researchers at the International Centre for Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Bangladesh, could not plan a randomized, controlled trial (RCT) because of ethical reasons. Now that we have data suggesting effectiveness as well as safety of the day-care based treatment for management of children with severe pneumonia, a RCT should be possible. Two hundred fifty-one children with severe pneumonia were enrolled at the Radda Clinic from June 2003 to May 2005. The mean age was 7±7 (2-55) months, 86% infants, 63% boys and 91% breast-fed. History of cough was present in 99% cases, fever in 89% and rapid breathing in 67% cases. Forty-four percent of children were febrile (≥38°C),

Because the patient is in his late 80s, and his dementia is interfering with his ability to eat independently, the patient would likely benefit from additional assistance with eating. Additionally, his surrogate decision-maker, who is also the patient's wife, likely views the patient's difficulty with eating as a stressful and burdensome situation. Both factors could motivate the surrogate decision-maker to support using a feeding tube. Existing studies have already established that surrogate decision-makers often support the use of feeding tubes when making decisions for patients with dementia, even in cases where the patient may become critically ill or die soon after the feeding tube is placed. In a study by Bae et al., surrogate-decision makers were interviewed after patients had died to understand how they made decisions about feeding tubes for their dying family members. Some surrogate decision-makers reported feeling guilty and even responsible for their inability to feed their family member in the way that they would have liked during their illness. Because many patients with dementia are unable to eat safely or obtain nutritional support in other ways, feeding tubes are often the only option for ensuring adequate nutritional intake. This can be seen as an ethical priority by surrogate decision-makers, who are motivated to extend the patient's life as much as possible. Finally, surrogate decision-makers have often witnessed or heard stories from medical professionals, family and friends about patients who were given feeding tubes and lived much longer than expected (Bae et al., 2013)</s>
